headline: Zettl‚Äôs Last-Minute Strike Carries Owls Past USF
content: TAMPA, Fla. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic men's soccer (10-3-1, 5-1-1) will have a chance to win the American Conference regular season title on Sunday night. The Owls outlasted USF (8-2-5, 4-2-1) in a 4-3 thriller on Wednesday to remain tied for first place in the league standings. Both teams were awarded a penalty kick in the first half, and both teams converted. First, it was USF in the 40th minute after an FAU handball on the edge of the box. Three minutes later, at the other end of the field, Mamadou Diarra was taken down in the penalty area and Oliver Moller-Jensen stepped forward to tie the game from the spot. The match went into halftime tied 1-1 before chaos took over in the final half hour. In the 61st minute, Felipe Santos found space well outside the box and picked the far corner for his first goal as an Owl. Less than a minute later, USF was awarded another penalty kick, this time for a foul in the box. They converted again to tie it 2-2. The Bulls then regained the lead in the 71st minute, but the advantage didn't last long. Four minutes after falling behind, Aboubacar Traore found himself on the other end of a Sebastian Zettl free kick and redirected home his fourth goal of the season to equalize 3-3. The Owls kept the pressure on in the final quarter of an hour and were rewarded with a last-minute winner. With 15 seconds left, Diarra found Zettl at the top of the penalty area, and the senior captain had just enough time and space to get a shot off. The strike beat the USF keeper to the bottom corner, stunning the home crowd and giving the Owls a shocking 4-3 road victory. Sebastian Zettl... AKA CAPTAIN CLUTCH!!! #WIPüèùÔ∏è@FAUAthletics | @American_Conf | @NCAASoccer pic.twitter.com/CKd685pWde ‚Äî Florida Atlantic Men's Soccer (@FAUMSoccer) October 30, 2025 The victory secures the Owls a first-round bye in the American Conference tournament and keeps them in contention for the regular season crown. To achieve the latter, they'll need more points on Sunday against Tulsa than Charlotte earns against Missouri State (i.e., if the Bears beat the 49ers, FAU needs just a tie). Kickoff between Florida Atlantic and Tulsa is set for 7 p.m. on Sunday at the FAU Soccer Stadium. Admission is free. For complete coverage of FAU men's soccer, follow us on X and Instagram (@FAUMSoccer).

headline: Owls Fall Short at USF to Conclude Season
content: TAMPA, Fla. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic's women's soccer's 2025 season came to an end on Thursday evening with a 2-1 loss at South Florida, conceding a last-minute goal. The Owls (4-12-3) went toe-to-toe with the Bulls (8-8-2) until the very end, with neither team finding the net until the final 10 minutes. The Owls quickly responded to USF's first goal of the night with Sutton Markee's first score of the season with four minutes remaining, before the Bulls hit the game-winner with just over a minute to go. Opportunities arrived early for Florida Atlantic, with two straight attempted shots at the 10-minute mark nearly evading the South Florida goalkeeper. With 22 minutes remaining, Sloane Young nearly connected with the net before another last-minute save. In total, the Owls out-shot the Bulls 8-5 in the opening 45 minutes, with five on-goal. The Bulls struck first in the 82nd minute. Four minutes later, a pass from Young set up a header to Markee for the equalizer, setting up the thrilling finish. South Florida connected with the game winner at 88:56, leaving little time for the Owls to answer back. Ashley Small, making her 15th start in the goal, recorded a clean first half with four saves and recorded a fifth in the second. She closes the season with three straight games with five plus saves. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date on all things Florida Atlantic women's soccer, follow FAU on social media @FAUWSoccer.

headline: Owls Fall in Four to Wichita State
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic Volleyball dropped a four-set battle, 3-1 (25-22, 25-29, 15-25, 25-18), against the Wichita State Shockers on Friday evening inside Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena. HOW IT HAPPENED The Owls scored first, but Wichita State took the lead after a 5-1 run to hold the early advantage. The Owls answered back with a 5-1 run of their own, sparked by Kayla Richardson's first kill of the day and a service ace from Emsley Venard, to bring the set even at six, 6-6. The Shockers regained the lead, sparking a pair of FAU timeouts through a 16-10 advantage. FAU battled back, producing an 8-3 run to cut the deficit to just one, 19-18, after a kill from Anna Hartman. The Owls kept things within one through a 22-21 Wichita State lead, but ultimately fell short as the Shockers closed the frame on a 3-1 run to take the first, 25-22. After battling through an 8-8 tie to open the second, Wichita State scored three unanswered points to retake the lead 11-8, forcing the Owls to call their first timeout of the second. Out of the break, the Owls rallied off a 5-1 run, capped off by a kill from Hartman, to retake the lead 13-12 and force Wichita State to call their first timeout of the set. Following a 15-15 tie, the Owls struggled to match the Shockers as Wichita State went on a 10-4 run to close out the second, 25-19, taking a two-set advantage heading to the third, 2-0. The Owls fought back in the third, opening the set on an 11-5 run. FAU kept up the pressure in the third, extending its lead to eight as a kill from Richardson gave the Owls the 20-12 lead, forcing Wichita State to call its second and final timeout. The Owls closed the set on a 5-3 to take the third, 25-15, and send the match to a fourth, 2-1. FAU and Wichita State battled through a 7-7 tie to open the fourth, but a 3-0 Shocker run broke things apart as the Owls called their first timeout of the set, trailing 10-7. The Owls kept things within three through a 16-13 Wichita State advantage, however, a 6-0 Wichita State run moved the deficit to nine, 22-13. The Owls fought back, producing a 5-2 run to try and cut into the Shockers' lead, but it just wasn't enough as Wichita State eventually claimed the fourth, 25-18, to close out the four-set match. STATS & NOTES Kierstin Bevelle, Olivia Hart, and Hartman led the way for the Owls in the match. Bevelle and Hart tied for a team-best 13 kills, while Hartman finished with 12 kills against the Shockers. Venard led the Owls in assists, dishing out a team-best 21, while also finishing with her fifth double-double of the season, adding a team second-best 10 digs in the match. Defensively, Isabelle Northam led the Owls' back row with a team-leading 15 digs. At the net, Richardson and Libby Ashline tied for a team-best four blocks on the night. As a team, the Owls outpaced the Shockers in kills, outscoring Wichita State 56-51. UP NEXT The Owls will close out the weekend on Sunday, Nov. 2, hosting the Tulsa Golden Hurricane for a 1 p.m. first serve inside Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena and on ESPN+. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic volleyball, follow @FAUVolleyball on X and Instagram, or like FAU Volleyball on Facebook.

headline: Owls Complete the 2025 American Championship
content: CONCORD, N.C. - Florida Atlantic's men's and women's cross country teams competed in the American Conference Championship on Saturday morning. The Owls competed in weather they are not typically used to. They raced in a colder climate than the weather in sunny Florida. The men started with an 8K to start the morning in Concord. In their third appearance at the American Championships, the men totaled 360 points on the day, finishing 12th. On the women's side, the Owls finished ninth overall with 267 points. On the women's side Rosa ten Berg, Elyssa Toal, Madison Brown, Anabell Reumann, Leah Helms, Sophie Dethier, Reese Anderson, and Morgan Pennington competed for Florida Atlantic. ten Berg came in first for the Owls. On the men's side, Paul Glick, Donovan Petty, Samuel Henery, Nazayer Franco, Noah Highsmith, and Nathan Webb represented FAU. QUICK HITS Women ten Berg finished with a time of 22:08.1 as the top Owl finisher for the second consecutive meet. Toal came in second for the Owls as she placed 53rd overall on the course with a time of 22:17.6 Seconds behind was Brown, running a 22:28.4. Finishing 64th overall, Reumann registered a 22:42.1 Helms finished 68th overall (22:52.4) Dethier (22:59.0) and Anderson (23:45.7) finished 70th and 81st overall in their first postseason run with the Owls Men As a team, Florida Atlantic recorded 360 points on the day Glick got it started for the Owls when he was the first to cross the finish line. Right behind was the freshman Petty with a time of 26:36.8. He recorded a career-best at the American Championships, last year running a 27:00.0. Back-to-back were Franco and Highsmith in their first appearance in an American Championship Webb placed 90th overall in his first postseason appearance. UP NEXT The Owls will conclude their cross country season with the NCAA South Regionals on Friday, Nov. 14, in Huntsville, Alabama, at John Hunt Park. FOLLOW THE OWLS For complete coverage of FAU cross country and track & field, follow us on social media @FAUXCTF

headline: Horan, Santiago, and Bostic Named All-Conference Recipents
content: BOCA RATON, Fla ‚Äì Following the conclusion of the 2025 regular season, Florida Atlantic women's soccer forwards Michelle Horan and Hailey Santiago have been named to the American All-Conference teams, while freshman Isabel Bostic was named All-Freshman Team, announced by the league on Sunday morning. Horan was named All-Conference Second Team after leading the Owls with seven assists on the season for a career high. "Michelle concludes her college career as one of the most exciting attacking players in FAU history. A four-year player, she has continued to develop her game each season and finished as one of our most impactful players," said Head Coach Patrick Baker. Horan totaled 3541 minutes in four seasons and started in all 22 games in 2025. The Cape Coral native finished the season with 11 points and two goals, with one of them a game-winner. She finishes her collegiate career with 46 starts in 73 matches, five goals, 14 assists, and 24 points. "Getting to play four years at the same institution with so many great people in a town that I love has been nothing short of amazing. Regardless of the highs and lows I experienced throughout my career, ending it on a high note with this recognition is sweet, and I'm super grateful to close out my time as an Owl like this!" said Horan. The New Jersey native Santiago finished her sophomore year with six goals in 22 games, with two of those being game-winning goals. "Hailey had a tremendous sophomore campaign and really proved she is one of the top forwards in the conference. She continues to grow and develop in our system. We are just scratching the surface of what she can become in the future," said Baker. Santiago started in all of the matches during the 2025 season. She registered 1,668 minutes to bring her total to 1,950 in her career as an Owl. As a sophomore, Santiago became an impactful player for Florida Atlantic. She concluded her sophomore year, recognized by the American on the All-Conference Third Team list. "I'm so very thankful for this recognition. said Santiago. "I wouldn't have been able to achieve it without the hard work from my teammates. Having my best friends on and off the field has made me want to work harder for them. I'm also very thankful for my coaches who believe in my abilities and push me every day." Bostic joined the Owls in the 2025 season from Ponte Verde, Florida. "Isabel enjoyed a promising freshman campaign - started and played quite a bit in a very competitive midfield. She has shown flashes of being a key contributor in our engine room. We look forward to her growth and development in 2026," said Baker. Bostic's first collegiate goal was an equalizer in the season opener against Loyola (MD). She made an appearance in 21 games with 13 starts during her freshman campaign. Bostic was named as one of the 11 on the All-Freshman Team list. "I am so thankful for this All-Freshmen recognition, and I really owe it all to my teammates", said Bostic, "Every single upperclassman put not only me, but everyone else before themselves, which led to my success on the field. I appreciate the time I got with them this season. Also, thank you to my coaches for pushing me to be better every day." For the full all-conference release from the American click here.

headline: Owls Host Tulsa with Regular Season Conference Title on the Line
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic men's soccer (10-3-1, 5-1-1) hosts Tulsa (4-8-3, 3-3-1) on Sunday night with a chance to win the American Conference regular season title. Kickoff is set for 7 p.m. All fans are encouraged to wear red to support the "RED OUT" theme. ABOUT THE OWLS A win over Tulsa would secure the Owls at least a share of the American Conference regular season title. A win + a Charlotte tie or loss vs. Missouri State and the Owls would have sole possession of the regular season title. If Charlotte loses, the Owls can tie Tulsa and still win the title outright. Prior to Sunday's game, 11 seniors will be recognized: Guilherme Pipolo, Eli Conway, Ednilson Voiles, Matthew Alfred, Enzo Rabot, Kerfalla Toure, Aboubacar Traore, Jozo Cancar, Andreas Raisanen, Fabrizio Cubeddu, and Sebastian Zettl. Traore, Zettl, and Mamadou Diarra each had an assist vs. USF -- the trio is now tied for third in program history with 15 for their respective careers. The record is 19. The Owls are looking to join the 2007, 2003, and 1989 teams with 11 wins in a season (3rd-most in a single season). 13 is the single-season record set by the 1996 team. ABOUT THE GOLDEN HURRICANE Tulsa is sixth in the American Conference standings and is hoping to secure one of the final spots in the postseason tournament. The Golden Hurricane is coming off a 0-0 draw with Missouri State on Wednesday. SERIES HISTORY The Owls will be looking for their first win over Tulsa. The Golden Hurricane lead the all-time series 4-0. WHAT'S NEXT The Owls have secured a first-round bye in the American Conference tournament. If they win the regular season title outright, the semifinals and championship game would be hosted at the FAU Soccer Stadium on November 12 and 15. FOLLOW US For complete coverage of FAU men's soccer, follow us on X and Instagram (@FAUMSoccer).

headline: Owls Close Fall Season in Georgia
content: FORSYTH, Ga. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic women's golf will compete in its third and final event of the fall, beginning Sunday at the Mercer Invitational in Forsyth, Georgia. Sunday will consist of 36 holes followed by a final round of 18 on Monday. The Lineup The Owls will make one change from the lineup that competed in the first two events of the fall. Sophomore Maddie Rathjen will get her first start after finishing 11th in last year's American Conference Championship. Nancy Cox and Tina Genoulaz will occupy the number one and two spots, while juniors Giulia Scarcello and Charlotte Perkins slot in at numbers four and five. The Course River Forest Golf Club will play as a par 71 at approximately 6,000 yards. The Field The field includes eight teams and 47 individuals. Round one begins with a shotgun start at 9 a.m. on Sunday. Live Scoring Live hole-by-hole results can be followed on Clippd Scoreboard. Owls on Social Media For complete coverage of FAU women's golf, follow us on X and Instagram (@FAUWGolf).

headline: Florida Atlantic Set to Travel for American Championships
content: CONCORD, N.C. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic's men's and women's cross country teams will travel to Concord to compete in the 2025 American Athletic Conference Cross Country Championships on Friday morning, hosted by Charlotte. This will mark the third American cross country championships that the Owls participate in. The races will be broadcasted on ESPN+. The women will run the 6K at 10 a.m., while the men will take on an 8K run, beginning at 9:15 a.m. Florida Atlantic looks to continue its successful season to close out 2025. LAST TIME OUT Women (Ed Holloway Classic) Florida Atlantic had two representatives on the night (Morgan Pennington and Reese Anderson). Anderson finished within the top 20, coming in at 16th with a time of 23:52. Men (Ed Holloway Classic) Senior Paul Glick was the next Owl to cross the finish line with a 27:11. The third runner for FAU was Donovan Petty, with a 27:22 (5:30 minutes per mile). Finishing within the top 30 was Noah Highsmith in his third race with Florida Atlantic. He finished with a 27:39 for his fastest time in an FAU uniform. Nate Webb and Nazayer Franco also ran for the Owls, finishing 33rd and 34th on the evening. SEASON HIGHLIGHTS The Owls started off the season at the Keiser Invitational. Madison Brown, Sophie Dethier, Anderson, and Pennington made their debut as Owls. On the men's side, Samuel Henery has competed very well in every race he has made an appearance. Webb, Franco, and Highsmith competed for the first time in an FAU uniform. UP NEXT The Owls will conclude their cross country season with the NCAA South Regionals on Friday, Nov. 14, in Huntsville, Alabama at John Hunt Park. FOLLOW THE OWLS For complete coverage of FAU cross country and track & field, follow us on social media. (@FAUXCTF)

headline: Owls Record Double-Digit Win Against Florida Tech
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic's men's basketball team kicked off year two with Head Coach John Jakus at the helm in a 110-68 exhibition victory over Florida Tech on Thursday evening at Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena. Five different players ended the night with double-digit scoring, which saw the Owls shoot 59.4% from the field while holding the opposing defense to 38.6%. FAU had 13 players see action. FIRST HALF Redshirt sophomore Devin Williams got things started for the Owls with the first bucket of the night. The lead grew and FAU was up by ten points, 14-4, from a made jumper outside the paint by junior Kanaan Carlyle 14 minutes into the game. Two players (Devin Vanterpool and Carlyle) recorded double-figures in the first 20 minutes, with 12 points each. FAU held a 20-point lead entering the locker room with a 54-34 advantage. SECOND HALF The Owls grew their 20-point lead, starting the second half with a steal by Carlyle that resulted in an alley-oop made by Xander Pintelon. With four minutes left, Amar Amkou hit back-to-back threes to make the game 98-58 in his first game dressing as an Owl. Liam Dayco-Green, Zion Sampaio, and Lachlan Smith saw action to close out the game. After a block by Amkou, Dayco-Green hit a contested three-pointer that improved the score 105-61. POSTGAME PRESSER STATS & NOTES Josiah Parker, Yohann Sissoko, Amkou, Vanterpool, and Carlyle each scored in double figures. Vanterpool led in scoring with 24. FAU scored 46 of its points in the paint, while Florida Tech scored 22. The Owls shot 54.2% from beyond the arc. Amkou tallied 17 points, shooting 100% from the field (five-for-five), beyond the arc (three-for-three), and at the line (four-for-four). Carlyle had a night sharing the ball with a total of 6 assists. He ended the night with a +/- of +34. The Owls totaled 20 assists on the night. Florida Atlantic only had 10 turnovers to Florida Tech's 22, and were able to score 30 points off of them. UP NEXT Florida Atlantic will start the regular season in Boca Raton as they host Boston College for the first time in program history on Monday, Nov. 3, at 7 p.m., airing on ESPNU. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date on all things FAU men's basketball, follow the Owls on social media @FAUMBB. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Phil Smith Kia/Phil Smith Acura.

headline: Owls Host Wichita State and Tulsa
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì The Florida Atlantic Owls are prepped for another important two-game homestand this weekend as the Owls host Wichita State on Friday, Oct. 31 at 6 p.m. ET, before closing out the weekend with a matchup against Tulsa on Sunday, Nov. 2 at 1 p.m. ET inside Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena. Fans can also catch both matches live on ESPN+. A LOOK AT THE OWLS FAU opens the weekend tied for fourth in the American with a 16-7 record this season and a 7-3 mark in American play. The Owls are riding a two-game winning streak after going 2-0 last weekend with a four-set win at Memphis and earning a road sweep at UAB. The Owls' offense is paced by Olivia Hart, Anna Hartman, and Erin Morrissey. Hart boasts a team-best 3.73 kills per set, while Hartman and Morrissey rank second and third on the team, averaging 2.66 and 2.41 kills per set, respectively. Florida Atlantic's assists leaders are Emsley Venard and Victoria Hensley. Venard boasts a team-leading 494 assists, averaging 6.10 per set, while Hensley ranks second on the team with 414 assists, dishing out 5.05 per set. The Owls' back row is anchored by libero Isabelle Northam, boasting a team-best 333 digs, averaging 4.27 per set. Hart ranks second on the team in digs with 238, averaging 2.90 per set. At the net, Florida Atlantic's block is led by Maggie Allred. Allred has registered a team-best 95 blocks this season, averaging 1.27 blocks per set. SCOUTING WICHITA STATE Wichita State enters Friday's contest at 14-8 overall and 6-4 in conference play. The Shockers have won just one of their last three matches and are just coming off a five-set loss against North Texas. The Shockers are led offensively by Sydney Dunning and Brooklyn Leggett, averaging 3.64 and 3.20 kills per set. Jordan Heatherly is Wichita State's assists leader, dishing out a team-best 727 assists and averaging 8.55 assists per set. Defensively, the Shockers' back row is led by Gabi Maas, Katie Galligan, and Dunning. Maas boasts a team-best 238 digs, averaging 3.97 digs per set, while Galligan and Dunning rank second and third, averaging 2.68 and 2.40 digs per set, respectively. At the net, Wichita State's block is led by Maddie Wilson, who has recorded a team-leading 101 blocks, averaging 1.23 blocks per set this season. SCOUTING TULSA Tulsa enters the weekend third in the American at 18-4 overall and 8-2 in league play. The Golden Hurricane is coming off a split weekend in which they fell in four sets against North Texas before closing out the weekend with a sweep over UTSA. The Golden Hurricane is led offensively by Lauren Eitler, Olivia Vance, Beth Bayless, and Kat Cooper. Vance boasts a team-leading 207 kills, averaging 2.62 per set, while Vance ranks second with 201 kills, but leads the team with 2.91 kills per set. Bayless and Cooper are tied for third with 187 kills apiece, averaging 2.63 and 2.37 kills per set, respectively. Brayden Hipp leads Tulsa and the American in assists, dishing out 784 assists this season and averaging 9.92 assists per set. The Golden Hurricane's back row is led by Lauren Patterson, tallying a team-best 306 digs and averaging 3.87 digs per set. Tulsa's blocking leader is Jill Hanson, who boasts a team-best 83 blocks, averaging 1.05 blocks per set. SERIES HISTORY Friday marks the fourth all-time meeting between Florida Atlantic and Wichita State and the second in Boca Raton. The Owls won the only meeting in Boca Raton, earning a 3-2 win on Friday, Oct. 27, 2023. However, the Owls have fallen short in the last two meetings against the Shockers, which included a defeat in the American Tournament championship last season on Nov. 24, 2024. Sunday also marks the fourth meeting between FAU and Tulsa. The Owls and Golden Hurricane have split the two meetings in Boca Raton, with FAU taking the last matchup 3-1 on Oct. 6, 2023. In the last meeting between the two squads, Tulsa took a four-set contest last season on Oct. 11, 2024. UP NEXT Following the weekend, the Owls will head out on their final regular-season road trip as they travel to Tulane on Friday, Nov. 7, and Rice on Saturday, Nov. 9. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic volleyball, follow @FAUVolleyball on X and Instagram, or like FAU Volleyball on Facebook.

headline: 2025 NFL Owls
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì Week 8 of the 2025 NFL season is in the books with five former Florida Atlantic Owls seeing action. Here's a rundown of how each performed during the eighth week (All gametimes listed below are Eastern): Active Owls (5) #0 Azeez Al-Shaair | LB | Houston Texans - For the second week in a row and fourth time of the season, Al-Shaair took part in 100% of Houston's defensive snaps. He logged four tackles, including a run stuff for no gain, as the Texans defeated the San Francisco 49ers by a score of 26-15. Texans' Record: 3-4 Next Game: vs. Denver ‚Äì Sunday, 1 p.m. (FOX) #88 Harrison Bryant | TE | Houston Texans - Also participating in Houston's 26-15 win over San Francisco, Bryant played a season high 22 snaps on offense. He also added 10 on special teams. Texans' Record: 3-4 Next Game: vs. Denver ‚Äì Sunday, 1 p.m. (FOX) #91 Trey Hendrickson | DE | Cincinnati Bengals - Hendrickson returned from a one-week absence to face off against the New York Jets. and made his presence felt early with a key third down run stuff to eventually force a turnover on downs. The Bengals came up just short in a 39-38 loss. Bengals' Record: 3-5 Next Game: vs. Chicago ‚Äì Sunday, 1 p.m. (CBS) #42 James Pierre | CB | Pittsburgh Steelers - Continuing to be a special teams ace, Pierre saw the field for a season high 20 snaps. The Steelers fell on primetime Sunday night to the Green Bay Packers by a score of 35-25. Steelers' Record: 4-3 Next Game: vs. Indianapolis ‚Äì Sunday, 1 p.m. (CBS) #26 Devin Singletary | RB | New York Giants - "Motor" had an increased role on both offense and special teams in the Giants' 38-20 defeat versus the defending Super Bowl champion Philadelphia Eagles. On kick return duties, he took two back for 51 yards, including a 31-yarder. On offense, he recorded a highlight reel play, going vertical on a third-and-seven and catching the ball on the run for a 28-yard reception. Giants' Record: 2-6 Next Game: vs. San Francisco ‚Äì Sunday, 1 p.m. (FOX) Inactive (1) #84 Zaire Mitchell-Paden | TE | New Orleans Saints - Mitchell-Paden was acquired by New Orleans on the Saturday before Week 8 and was inactive in the Saints' 23-3 loss to the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. Saints' Record: 1-7 Next Game: at L.A. Rams ‚Äì Sunday, 4:05 p.m. (FOX) Practice Squad (3) #58 Evan Anderson | DT | San Francisco 49ers #62 Federico Maranges | C | Seattle Seahawks #73 Brandon Walton | OT | Carolina Panthers Check fausports.com each Thursday to see how each Owl did the previous week along with a preview of their respective team's next game.
